_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1. Executive Summary



This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:

- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5

- Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR ?68

- California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR ?5189

- Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR ?1910.119



Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.



This program is intended to be a "living document". As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, Wawona Frozen Foods has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities. 



1.1 Wawona Frozen Foods, Risk and Process Safety Management Program



This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Wawona Frozen Foods has updated their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following processes which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 



Process Name                   | Process Chemical                | Process Quantity(lbs.)

P1 MER, WER, & Spiral Systems    Anhydrous Ammonia                 23,000

P2 Chiller & IQF Systems         Anhydrous Ammonia                 12,000





Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses, and physical property damage.



Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public

safety. We have: 

1. Prepared a unified program based on the PSM regulation to meet CalARP and RMP obligations as well

2. Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general business practices

3. Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)



The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures, and practices that will help our employees and neighbors protect themselves.



1.2 Process Descriptions



1.2.1 Facility Overview



Wawona Frozen Foods - Alluvial operates a commercial cold storage in Clovis, CA. The facility has ammonia refrigeration systems that provide refrigeration capacity to the following:

(1) Blast Tunnel

(12) Refrigerated Rooms

(1) Spiral Freezer

(1) IQF Area

(2) IQF Freezers

(2) IQF Precoolers



1.2.2 Facility Location



Wawona Frozen Foods Alluvial is located at 100 W. Alluvial, Clovis, CA 93611. The latitude and longitude of the low pressure receiver is 36.844151, -119.714391. The facility is located approximately 1 mile northwest of state highway 168 in a rural area surrounded primarily by civilian housing.



Flood Hazards

According to FEMA Flood Map Service, the facility is located in "an area of minimal flood hazard".



Seismic Susceptibility

Wawona Frozen Foods Alluvial is not located in an Alquist-Priolo Fault Zone as defined by the California Department of Conservation. In addition, a review of United States Geological Survey (USGS) fault maps revealed that there are no faults in close proximity to the site. The USGS 2018 One-Year Model revealed that Wawona Frozen Foods Alluvial has a 1-2% chance of experiencing "potentially minor-damage" due to ground shaking in 2018.

ion.



Most control valve groups are located on the roof to provide easy access. The refrigeration machinery is contained within or outside the machinery area/room. A partial list of systems components includes:

Process Chemistry



The refrigeration systems employed at Wawona Frozen Foods utilize both flooded and pumped overfeed configuration. The function and thermodynamics of each major component type in each system is summarized below:



High Pressure Receivers

The purpose of each high pressure receiver is to provide a safe location to add and store high pressure liquid ammonia in the refrigeration systems. Each high pressure receiver receives high pressure liquid from the condensers and supplies high pressure liquid to each zone of refrigeration and liquid recirculators. Each high pressure receiver is also used to provide storage for ammonia not being used in each process at any given moment. Each high pressure receiver is equipped with a main liquid feed shut-off valve (king valve) that is clearly labeled and can be used to stop the flow of ammonia throughout each system. Under normal conditions, the high pressure receivers contain high pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Flooded Accumulators

The purpose of each flooded accumulator is to provide a supply of low pressure liquid ammonia to the evaporators. Each accumulator is equipped with an expansion valve which expands the high pressure liquid into a low temperature and pressure liquid as it enters the vessel. The flooded accumulators supply, by gravity, low pressure liquid to the associated evaporators. Liquid and vapor returned from the evaporators is separated inside the flooded accumulators to allow only the vapor to be returned to the low pressure receiver. Under normal conditions, the flooded accumulators contain low pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Intercoolers

The purpose of each intercooler is to desuperheat a

nd condense the booster discharge gas and to supply low pressure liquid to the flooded accumulators and liquid recirculators. Each intercooler also receives and subcools liquid from the high pressure receivers in order to supply lower pressure liquid to the flooded accumulators and liquid recirculators. Ammonia vapor is piped from the top of each intercooler into the suction inlet of each high stage compressor. Each intercooler is equipped with a high level float switch that is wired to shut down the compressors in the event of a high level situation. This prevents liquid ammonia from entering the compressors. Under normal conditions, the intercoolers contain low pressure liquid and vapor.



Subcooler

The subcooler receives and subcools liquid from the high pressure receiver in order to supply subcooled liquid to the liquid recirculator. The subcooler is a heat exchanger that uses a supply of low temperature ammonia to cool high pressure liquid ammonia. On the low temperature side, the subcooler is equipped with an expansion valve which expands high pressure liquid into a low temperature and pressure liquid as it enters the heat exchanger. On the high pressure side, high pressure liquid is piped from the high pressure receiver and into spiral piping inside the subcooler. The low pressure liquid in the vessel absorbs heat from the high pressure liquid in the spiral piping. The subcooled high pressure liquid exits the subcooler and is supplied to the liquid recirculator. Under normal conditions, the subcooler contains low and high pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Low Temperature Recirculators

The purpose of each low temperature recirculator is to provide a supply of low pressure liquid that can be used in low temperature evaporators throughout the facility. Each low temperature recirculator receives liquid from each intercooler or subcooler and supplies, by gravity, low pressure liquid to the ammonia pumps mounted underneath each associated vessel. Liquid and

vapor returned from the evaporators is separated inside the recirculators to allow only the vapor to be piped to the suction of each low stage compressor. Each low temperature recirculator is equipped with a high level float switch that is wired to shut down the compressors in the event of a high level situation. This prevents liquid ammonia from entering the compressors. Under normal conditions, the low temperature recirculators contain low pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Oil Pots

The purpose of the oil pots is to provide a safe location to drain oil from each refrigeration system. The oil pots receive liquid ammonia and oil from the recirculators, intercoolers, or low pressure receiver and vent ammonia vapor back to each associated vessel. The oil pots are equipped with spring-return oil drain valves which are used to drain oil from the systems as needed. Under normal conditions, the oil pots contain low pressure liquid ammonia, low pressure vapor ammonia, and refrigerant oil.



Air-Cooling Evaporators (Flooded)

The purpose of the air-cooling evaporators is to remove heat from the air in order to maintain a predetermined space temperature. The air-cooling evaporators receive liquid from the flooded accumulators. The evaporators contain a set of continuous coils through which the low pressure liquid flows. Due to the low pressures and temperatures maintained in the evaporator, the liquid refrigerant absorbs a great deal of heat from the surrounding area and evaporates. To increase the rate of heat removed, the evaporators use an electric fan to move warm air over the coils of cold liquid ammonia. Once the liquid has evaporated to form low temperature and pressure vapor, it returns to the supplying vessel. Under normal conditions, the air-cooling evaporators contain low pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Air-Cooling Evaporators (Pumped Overfeed)

The purpose of the air-cooling evaporators is to remove heat from the air in order to maintain a predetermine

d space temperature. The air-cooling evaporators receive liquid from the recirculators. The evaporators contain a set of continuous coils through which the low pressure liquid flows. Due to the low pressures and temperatures maintained in the evaporator, the liquid refrigerant absorbs a great deal of heat from the surrounding area and evaporates. To increase the rate of heat removed, the evaporators use an electric fan to move warm air over the coils of cold liquid ammonia. Once the liquid has evaporated to form low temperature and pressure vapor, it returns to the supplying vessel. Under normal conditions, the air-cooling evaporators contain low pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Air-Cooling Evaporators (Direct Expansion)

The purpose of the air-cooling evaporators is to remove heat from the air in order to maintain a predetermined space temperature. The air-cooling evaporators receive liquid from the high pressure receivers. Each evaporator is equipped with an expansion valve which reduces the pressure and temperature of the liquid as it enters the evaporator. The evaporators contain a set of continuous coils through which the low pressure liquid flows. Due to the low pressures and temperatures maintained in the evaporator, the liquid refrigerant absorbs a great deal of heat from the surrounding area and evaporates. To increase the rate of heat removed, the evaporators use an electric fan to move warm air over the coils of cold liquid ammonia. Once the liquid has evaporated to form low temperature and pressure vapor, it exits the evaporator and is returned to the low pressure receiver.



Plate and Frame Heat Exchanger

The purpose of the plate and frame heat exchanger is to remove heat from the secondary coolant being pumped through it. The plate and frame heat exchanger receives liquid from a flooded accumulator  where it flows through the channels in the plates and absorbs the heat from the secondary coolant on the opposite side of each plate. Low pressure l

iquid and vapor exits the plate and frame heat exchanger and is returned to the flooded accumulator. Under normal conditions, the plate and frame heat exchanger contains low pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Shell and Tube Heat Exchanger

The purpose of the shell and tube heat exchanger is to remove heat from the secondary coolant being pumped through it. The shell and tube heat exchanger receives liquid from a flooded accumulator where it is contained within the shell of the heat exchanger and surrounds the tubes containing secondary coolant. Low pressure liquid and vapor exits the shell and tube heat exchanger and is returned to the flooded accumulator. Under normal conditions, the shell and tube heat exchanger contains low pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Low Pressure Receiver

The purpose of the low pressure receiver is to prevent liquid from entering the compressors. The low pressure receiver receives vapor from the flooded accumulators and recirculators and separates any residual liquid from the vapor to allow only the vapor to be piped to the suction of each compressor. Liquid in the low pressure receiver drains by gravity into the liquid transfer vessel. The low pressure receiver is equipped with a high level float switch that is wired to shut down the compressors in the event of a high level situation. This prevents liquid ammonia from entering the compressors. Under normal conditions, the low pressure receiver contains low pressure vapor ammonia.



Liquid Transfer Vessel

The purpose of the liquid transfer vessel is to transfer liquid from the low side of the refrigeration system back to the high pressure receiver. The liquid transfer vessel receives liquid from the low pressure receiver. Once the liquid level in the liquid transfer vessel reaches the float switch, the three way solenoid valve is energized for a period of time causing the liquid transfer vessel to become subject to high pressure and activating the transfer pump which moves the li

quid to the high pressure receiver. Under normal conditions the liquid transfer vessel and transfer pump can contain either high or low pressure liquid and vapor.



Compressors

The purpose of the compressors is to raise the temperature and pressure of the low pressure gas in order to reject the heat absorbed in the evaporator to the atmosphere. The compressors receive low pressure vapor from the low pressure receiver, intercooler, or recirculator and discharge high pressure vapor to the evaporative condensers. The compressors are equipped with high discharge pressure cutouts to shut the equipment off if the pressure exceeds the setpoint. Under normal conditions, the compressors contain both high and low pressure vapor ammonia.



Evaporative Condensers

The purpose of the evaporative condensers is to reject the heat absorbed in the evaporators to the atmosphere. The evaporative condensers receive high pressure, superheated vapor from the compressors and supply high pressure liquid to the high pressure receiver. The condensers use air and water to cool the warm ammonia as it passes through a series of tubes within the condenser. As the cooling medium of air and water draws the heat from the vapor, the refrigerant condenses into a liquid and flows to the high pressure receiver. Under normal conditions, the evaporative condensers contain high pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Auto-Purgers

The purpose of each auto-purger is to remove non-condensable gases from each system without requiring the system to be manually opened. Each auto-purger consists of the following components: water bubbler, foul gas line, liquid line, suction line, water line, drain line, and remote purge point solenoid valves. Each auto-purger removes non-condensable gases by refrigerating the foul gas so that the ammonia vapor condenses to liquid and can be returned to the system. The non-condensable gases are removed from each system through the water bubbler. Under normal conditions, the aut

o-purgers contain small quantities of ammonia and water.





1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps



1.3.1 General 



We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meeting we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.



Wawona Frozen Foods has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration processes. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter and hard copy binders. 



1.3.2 Anhydrous Ammonia



The ammonia refrigeration processes at the Wawona Frozen Foods facility are an integral part of the overall business and operates year round. It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.



Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration process and keep active records of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the process is checked frequently by one of the outside refrigeration contractors that we use. These contractors also assist in performing the annual mechanical integrity inspection of our ammonia equipment. 



1.4 Five Year Accident History



Wawona Frozen Foods has had no accidental release within the last five (5) years.



1.5 Emergency Action and Response Plan



Wawona Frozen Foods' emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:

- Cal/OSHA's Emergency Action Plan - Title 8 CCR ?3220

- U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Emergency Action Plans - Title 29 CFR ?1910.38

- Cal/OSHA's Process Safety Management [Eme

rgency Response Program Requirements] - Title 8 CCR ?5189(n)

- U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Process Safety Management [Emergency Planning and Response Requirements] - Title 29 CFR ?1910.119(n)

- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4.5 ?2765.1-2765.2

- USEPA Risk Management Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 40 CFR ?68.95

- California Hazardous Materials Business Plan (HMBP) [Emergency Response Plans and Procedures] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4 ?2731

- California "Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response" (HAZWOPER) - Title 8 CCR Title 8 ?5192(q)

- Federal "Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response" (HAZWOPER) - Title 29 CFR ?1910.120(q)



Wawona Frozen Foods has elected to use either a defensive or offensive strategy as a first response to a hazardous material release.



Selected employees who have received HAZWOPER Technician training shall take defensive or offensive steps to bring the release under control. Response activities would be done in coordination with the Local Fire Department and their Hazardous Materials Response Team. 



Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.



1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Wawona Frozen Foods has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, Wawona Frozen Foods continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.



By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved Wawona Frozen Foods's ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that Wawona Frozen Foods's management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program

is being implemented.



Wawona Frozen Foods has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.



In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, Wawona Frozen Foods has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation.



For the future, Wawona Frozen Foods now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a "living document". It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for Wawona Frozen Foods employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program Wawona Frozen Foods will continue to maintain overall plant worker and public safety.
